anyone know any good guides for doing this stuff for yourself. I dont want to deploy with people and have them shut down.

@myusuf3 Writing something similar to the scale of our services (I help run ep.io) is unnecessary; for personal things, you just need a few VPSs, and a decent database config. It won't be as redundant, and it will cost a bit more, but you avoid lock-in.
That said, most of the services don't have much lock-in, as there's very little or no code modification required. It's not like GAE where you had to reinvent everything.

@myusuf3 While I would still recommend looking at the good hosted solutions if you need any kind of scaling, if you want to do it yourself Eric Holscher has a nice sample of using Chef to deploy a Django app on his github. There is also a Chef group here.
I've only had the privilege of trying ep.io so far, and it is freakin awesome! It makes deployment on webfaction seem like a hassle.
Like @andrewgodwin said, the code is the same and you could deploy it anywhere. But having a service to deploy the master branch with one command saves you more time than you think.
@myusuf3 I can strongly recommend Fabric if you want to do it yourself. It's a really great Python-based tool that makes deployment a lot less painful. http://fabfile.org

@rlofthouse I firmly believe support is one of the few areas in hosting you can still compete on (along with stability, price, and ease of deployment). It's one of the reasons people use Rackspace Cloud over EC2 - trying to get support out of Amazon can be like getting blood from a stone.
Besides, I've used many hosting companies in the past, and I know which, as a developer, I felt most happy using, so I'm trying to emulate those.
One lot you could email at 2am on a Sunday about small issues, like clock drift on a VPS, and they'd reply within 5 minutes having fixed it.
given the general intelligence of their clients, that's probably fair, though
